pages.text: Border Collies have three genes that determine how they look. These are the B Locus, D Locus, and merle gene. The B Locus determines whether the dog has black or red fur, while the D Locus determines whether they are diluted to lilac or not. The merle gene determines if they show merle patterning or not.

The B Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'B' and the recessive 'b'. The 'B' allele creates black fur, while the 'b' allele creates red fur. Dogs with one copy of 'b' will carry the red trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for red pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'b' will always create either red carriers or red puppies.
pages.title: B Locus

pages.text: The D Locus has two potential alleles, the dominant 'D' and the recessive 'd'. The 'D' allele does not affect the coat's color, while the 'd' allele is a dilute that creates pale, or lilac, fur. Dogs with one copy of 'd' will carry the dilution trait and may pass it on to pups, providing the potential for diluted pups depending on the other parent. Dogs with two copies of 'd' will always create either dilute carriers or lilac puppies.
pages.title: D Locus

pages.text: Understanding of merle is limited, but from our understanding dogs will either be merle or they won't. Dogs that have the merle trait have a distinctive patchy look. Two merle parents will always produce a merle pup, while merle bred to a non-merle can produce a pup with or without the merle trait.
